If you press the 'cancel' button, all data regarding the current transect will be lost.
If you press the 'send' button, the data for the current transect will be sent (saved), and you can start a new transect.

This action cannot be undone, be careful.
Surveys involve conducting patrols along the beach to detect possible traces of turtle nesting during the period between June 1st and October 31st.
It is recommended to carry out these patrols between 22:00 and 08:00 the following day, although the early hours of the night are the most suitable for this.
When a turtle emerges from the sea onto the beach to nest, it crawls using its flippers as if they were legs. This movement leaves a very distinctive track ascending towards the beach.

When it finds a suitable place, it digs the nest, lays the eggs, covers it, and returns to the sea, leaving a track with the same characteristics as the ascent but in the direction of the sea, often with a line in the middle to drag a tube through which the eggs have come out.

An even greater challenge would be encountering hatchlings between August and October, emerging from undetected nests and walking on the sand towards the sea. This is extremely unlikely, as they hatch at night and are very small.
If we find small hatchlings or a large turtle alive or dead outside the water, we should quickly call:

You can bring a flashlight or a headlamp with a red light, although it is rarely necessary for walking. We will use it if we are unsure about something during the transect, but moonlight is usually sufficient. Whenever possible, keep the flashlight off and walk quietly. If we do not have enough light to observe tracks, we will hold the flashlight with our arm extended towards the ground to highlight the sand and relief better. Never point the flashlight towards the water, as it could scare off a turtle if one is trying to come ashore.
You can put red cellophane paper on a flashlight or in front of the mobile phone flashlight.

We can take advantage of the walk to inform and raise awareness among people or groups we encounter on the beach (athletes, families, anglers, and others) to help us by calling 112 if they witness nesting or find tracks. Always at our discretion and willingness.
We will start a transect in a specific area of the beach and activate the "START TRANSECT" button.
We will walk along the beach, by the seashore, observing the first meters of the undulating dry sand.

Once we finish our route, we will access the "START TRANSECT" section and press "STOP TRANSECT", which will take us to a screen where we must fill in the following fields. If we find the beach plowed by a machine that could erase the tracks, we will record the number of people informed, note interesting observations, etc., and send the data.
